TDCE-PII-01.name: Personal Identifiable Information
TDCE-PII-01.description: Data that can directly or indirectly identify a natural person, including name, address, email, phone number, national identifiers (SSN, NI number), date of birth, and online identifiers (IP address, cookie IDs). Subject to privacy regulations across all major jurisdictions. Breach triggers mandatory notification obligations.

TDCE-PII-02.name: Special Category / Sensitive PII
TDCE-PII-02.description: Data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, genetic data, biometric data, health data, sex life or sexual orientation. Subject to heightened processing restrictions and explicit consent requirements. Many jurisdictions prohibit processing unless specific legal bases apply.

TDCE-PCI-01.name: Cardholder Data (CHD)
TDCE-PCI-01.description: Primary Account Number (PAN), cardholder name, expiration date, and service code as defined by PCI DSS. PAN is the defining element — if PAN is present, PCI DSS applies. Must be rendered unreadable anywhere it is stored. Retention must be minimised and justified by business need.

TDCE-PCI-02.name: Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD)
TDCE-PCI-02.description: Full track data (magnetic stripe or chip equivalent), CAV2/CVC2/CVV2/CID, and PINs or PIN blocks. Must never be stored after authorisation, even if encrypted. The most restrictive data type in PCI DSS — no business justification permits post-authorisation retention.

TDCE-PHI-01.name: Protected Health Information
TDCE-PHI-01.description: Individually identifiable health information held or transmitted by a covered entity or business associate, including diagnoses, treatment records, test results, prescription data, and health insurance information. Combines PII with clinical data, creating dual regulatory obligations. Breach notification required within 60 days under HIPAA.

TDCE-FIN-01.name: Financial Records
TDCE-FIN-01.description: Financial statements, transaction records, trading data, risk models, audit trails, and regulatory filings. Subject to integrity and retention requirements under financial services regulations. Material non-public financial information triggers insider trading obligations. Operational resilience regulations (DORA, FCA) mandate availability and recovery controls.

TDCE-IP-01.name: Intellectual Property
TDCE-IP-01.description: Trade secrets, proprietary algorithms, research data, product designs, manufacturing processes, and competitive intelligence. Protection derives from trade secret law (DTSA, EU Trade Secrets Directive) rather than prescriptive regulations — the obligation is to maintain 'reasonable measures' to preserve secrecy. Loss is often irreversible as trade secret status cannot be restored once disclosed.

TDCE-IP-02.name: Source Code
TDCE-IP-02.description: Application source code, infrastructure-as-code, configuration scripts, and build pipelines. Exposure enables vulnerability discovery, backdoor insertion, and supply chain attacks. Requires integrity controls (signing, access-controlled repositories) as well as confidentiality. Supply chain risk is amplified when source code includes embedded credentials or infrastructure topology.

TDCE-SEC-01.name: Security Telemetry / Logs
TDCE-SEC-01.description: SIEM data, IDS/IPS alerts, firewall logs, authentication logs, vulnerability scan results, and threat intelligence feeds. Exposure reveals defensive capabilities, detection gaps, and incident response posture. Integrity is critical — tampered logs undermine forensic investigations and compliance evidence. Retention periods driven by regulatory and forensic requirements.

TDCE-SEC-02.name: Credentials / Secrets
TDCE-SEC-02.description: Passwords, API keys, tokens, service account credentials, database connection strings, and other authentication secrets. Compromise enables direct unauthorised access without exploiting any vulnerability. Must never appear in source code, logs, or error messages. Secrets management (vault, rotation, just-in-time access) is the primary control domain.

TDCE-SEC-03.name: Cryptographic Key Material
TDCE-SEC-03.description: Private keys, symmetric encryption keys, key-encrypting keys, HSM master keys, and certificate private keys. Compromise of key material renders all data encrypted under those keys effectively unprotected. Requires hardware-backed storage (HSM/TPM) for high-assurance environments. Key lifecycle management (generation, distribution, rotation, destruction) is as important as storage protection.

TDCE-GOV-01.name: Government Classified
TDCE-GOV-01.description: Information classified under national security frameworks (OFFICIAL-SENSITIVE, SECRET, TOP SECRET or equivalent). Processing requires accredited facilities, cleared personnel, and approved cryptographic implementations. Cross-border transfer restrictions apply. Handling requirements are dictated by the classifying authority and are non-negotiable — the organisation cannot risk-accept lower controls.

TDCE-OPS-01.name: Operational Technology Data
TDCE-OPS-01.description: SCADA process values, PLC configurations, engineering schematics, safety instrumented system (SIS) parameters, and building management system data. Integrity and availability take priority over confidentiality — incorrect process values or unavailable control systems create safety risks. Air-gapped or zone-segmented architectures are standard. Patch cycles are measured in months or years due to availability requirements.

TDCE-BUS-01.name: General Business Data
TDCE-BUS-01.description: Internal communications, project plans, meeting notes, organisational charts, non-sensitive operational documents, and internal policies. Not intended for public release but loss or exposure has limited regulatory or legal consequences. Standard access control and classification labelling are sufficient. Represents the baseline data protection level for enterprise information.
